page.title: 01Walsingham
page.content: The villages of{Great and Little} Walsingham founded in Anglo_Saxon times lie in the valley of the little{ {River Stiffkey}.The well_wooded arable land is gently undulating all below seventy metres above sea_level. Gt. Walsingham,by far the larger in acreage,only equals Lt.Walsingham in population.The older flint_built houses nestle around a village green.On three occasions it has received the{Best_Kept Village} award.The main employment is agricultural although it does possess a small iron foundry. Lt.Walsingham until the dissolution of the Monasteries was second only to Canterbury as a place of pilgrimages.Since the 1930's both main religions have worked to restore it to its former importance and glory.
